definition: lit. target of a multitude of arrows (idiom); the butt of public criticism/attacked on all sides
abbr. for 眾議院|众议院[Zhong4 yi4 yuan4], House of Representatives
many/numerous/crowd/multitude
variant of 眾|众[zhong4]
arrow/dart/straight/to vow/to swear/old variant of 屎[shi3]
(possessive particle, literary equivalent of 的[de5])/him/her/it
see 的士[di1 shi4]
of/~'s (possessive particle)/(used after an attribute)/(used to form a nominal expression)/(used at the end of a declarative sentence for emphasis)
aim/clear
really and truly

sentences.english: Now Honda has been a target again.
sentences.chinese: 现在本田再一次成为众矢之的。

sentences.english: Every other country complains about your bank-secrecy laws.
sentences.chinese: 《银行保密法》是众矢之的，其他国家全都怨声载道。

sentences.english: Marotta's arrival will also spell the end for under-fire Alessio Secco.
sentences.chinese: 他的到来也会结束众矢之的的赛科在尤文的生涯。

sentences.english: And almost everyone disliked Muslims and Buddhists more than any other group.
sentences.chinese: 而穆斯林和佛教徒几乎是众矢之的，没人待见。

sentences.english: Often, a large group of people against her thoughtlessness.
sentences.chinese: 往往会得罪一大帮的人，成为众矢之的。

sentences.english: She was single but it seems no longer. This man has become the envy of Kournikova admirers.
sentences.chinese: 而费多拉夫则成了库尔尼科娃众多崇拜者的众矢之的。

definition: a matter for ridicule/an object of ridicule/laughingstock
public enemy
to be thoroughly discredited/to fall into disrepute
sb or sth detested by all/target of scorn/anathema/cf. 老鼠過街，人人喊打|老鼠过街，人人喊打[lao3 shu3 guo4 jie1 , ren2 ren2 han3 da3]
scapegoat/sacrificial lamb/same as 替罪羊
to condemn in speech and in writing (idiom)/to denounce by word and pen
the masses rise to attack it (idiom); Everyone is against the idea./universally abhorrent
sb condemned by history (idiom)
sacrificial victim/sb who is expendable/item sold at a loss
scapegoat
lit. for one's face to reach rock bottom/to be thoroughly discredited (idiom)
to spit on and curse/to revile
to lose one's standing/to have one's reputation swept away/a complete defeat and fall from grace
public anger/popular indignation
to stand out (among a group)/distinguished
to throw stones at sb who fell down a well (idiom); to hit a person who is down
